en.value: Now that you know the basics, we're going to practise asking and answering three simple questions. You already know how to answer the first one!
In English, "I'm..." is the easiest way to say your name. It means the same as "My name is...".
Benjamin: I'm Benjamin. Nice to meet you!
Hello, what's your name? Hi, [k]I'm[/k] Omar.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Where are you from? [k]I'm from[/k] Turkey.
Select the correct answer to the question "What's your name?".

We can also use "I'm ..." to give our age. Most English speakers will use this more commonly than "I'm ... years old". You might not know how to count in English yet. We will learn all the numbers later in the course.
This is a common way of giving your age.
Match the question to the answer.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Hi, my name is Chris. [k]What's[/k] your name?
[k]I'm from[/k] France. And you, where are you from?
I am 27 years old. How old are you?
Select the answer to the question you hear.
Select the question that matches the answer you hear.
Where are you from? [k]I'm from[/k] France.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Type the correct form of the verb "to be" into the gap.
Fill in the gap using the image.
[k]My name[/k] [k]is[/k] [k]Patrick. I am from[/k] [k]England. I'm[/k] [k]20 years[/k] [k]old.[/k]
Write or record a response to: Hello! What's your name?
Hello, my name is David. What's your name?
Have a quick look at the words in bold in the examples below. You'll have already seen most of them in previous lessons. They show who or what we are talking about and are called personal pronouns.
Some personal pronouns refer to a single person or object, while others refer to a group of people or objects. The singular personal pronouns are:
This sentence talks about one person.
Good to know: we use "it" to refer to singular objects (not people).
My car is red. = It is red.
The book is good. = It is good.
When telling someone my book is red, I should say:
Here are the plural personal pronouns. Notice how "you" is the same whether it refers to one person or more.
When talking about my two friends from England, which form of "to be" should I use?
And when talking about my Spanish friend I should say:
You have already learned the verb "to be" in its different forms. In a sentence, we have to match the correct form of the verb with the personal pronoun.
When talking about myself, which form of "to be" should I use?
Click on the personal pronoun you hear.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
